abstract: Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple, could ignore the call of the motherboard no longer. He is going back to work — this time at Fusion-io, a start-up company that tweaks computers to let them tap vast amounts of storage at very quick rates.
lead_paragraph: Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple, could ignore the call of the motherboard no longer. He is going back to work — this time at Fusion-io, a start-up company that tweaks computers to let them tap vast amounts of storage at very quick rates.

headline.main: Wozniak Accepts Post at a Storage Start-Up

abstract: There are now 15,000 programs available on the App Store, and so many more are flooding in that Apple’s army of screeners can’t even keep up.
snippet: There are now 15,000 programs available on the App Store, and so many more are flooding in that Apple’s army of screeners can’t even keep up.
lead_paragraph: Who was it who wrote, in March 2008, just after Apple announced its intention to create an online app store for the iPhone, "You're witnessing the birth of a third major computer platform: Windows, Mac OS X, iPhone"?

headline.main: So Many iPhone Apps, So Little Time
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue

abstract: Arthur Rock, who backed Fairchild Semiconductor, Intel and Apple, invested with Bernard L. Madoff, according to a list made public in bankruptcy court filings Thursday.
snippet: Arthur Rock, who backed Fairchild Semiconductor, Intel and Apple, invested with Bernard L. Madoff, according to a list made public in bankruptcy court filings Thursday.
lead_paragraph: One of Silicon Valley’s legends, Arthur Rock, invested with Bernard L. Madoff, according to the customer list made public Wednesday in bankruptcy court filings.

headline.main: Arthur Rock, Legendary V.C., Invested With Bernard Madoff
